content: Nice puzzle! I'm curious why you added the tag "Algebra". Would you consider adding another tag along the lines of "Bitwise Operations"?

Good

I tested the puzzle and it was great. I suggest you to publish it on the website. Notice me by a reply when you do and I will be happy to give my approval. I think the difficulty is in between medium or easy. In many scientific paper, we refer to the "link code matrix" as an incidence matrix (Graph Theory). It could be a more appropriate name for the matrix.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incidence_matrix#:~:text=In%20mathematics%2C%20an%20incidence%20matrix,for%20each%20element%20of%20Y.

Goal
* Example: Suggest to change "Link code matrix" to "The corresponding link code matrix is" for clarity.

* Example: Suggest to format the link code matrix itself using the
```
multi-line
monospace
syntax
```.

Input/Stub generator
* Please use consistent variable names in Input section and stub generator.

Output
* Please format "k" and "l_k" as [[variables]].

* Please format "AMBIGUOUS" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.
Thank you for the great suggestions, I couldn't find a good format for the matrix, with this syntax it looks much nicer!

Thank you! Although you're right that the link code matrix is very similar to the incidence matrix, it has a slightly different meaning in graph theory (relationship between different sets). Hence, it is called link code matrix in the literature of all-optical failure localization to distinguish the two.
Corrected, thanks for the suggestion!

I've tried to add some visualisation in the banner of the puzzle but unfortunately you can't really do that in the description. If you look at the theory behind, m-trails are simple paths in the topology graphs. Indeed, creating m-trails is a hard task as you need to make sure that the alarm codes (rows of the matrix) are unique for each link, as well as the m-trails are connected paths in the graph (columns of the matrix). For single link failure localization efficient heuristics exist where you start with a unique matrix and swap the codes until the columns form an m-trail. However, for arbitrary multiple failures the problem becomes NP-complete, and we can only solve some specific failure patterns efficiently.

Good question! Generating alarm code matrices for single and multiple link failures has really nice algebraic background and I had that in mind. Although you're right that the checking part in the puzzle is mainly focused on bitwise operations, I don't want to change the description/tag after being published on the site.
Okay, your call, but I do think the inexperienced programmer could really use a push in the bitwise direction via a tag. I think the description is perfectly fine as-is.
Thank you for the detailed answer. And it finally dawned on me! I understood how to solve the problem.
